pros: Good Benefits, and Work-life balance.
cons: The corporate office is HEAVY with many Redundant departments and a HEAVY middle management layer. The Budget owners take the budget allocation as their own wealth (assuming the Power of Attorney to spend that money per their PERSONAL wishes) and they may use it in whatever way they want. Middle management misuses their flexi-time and work-life balance. Not inclusive workplace, and extremely high discrimination towards someone who is visibly a minority. Co-workers tend to ask such questions, "how did YOU get here!" No one coworker, but many put the emphasis on YOU! it makes it quite obvious they may want to keep some favorite "corporate" departments pet in their close-knit community/ethnicity.

cons: Toxic work environment. It is a giant, unwieldy gov't organization, where they use negative feedback as the way to police their staff. One person will do something wrong and they punishment will go out to all. Oh, and be ready for your payroll to never be correct.

review_title: Overall positive experience despite some frustrating systematic cons.
pros: 1. Very flexible with remote work. 2. Most co-workers are passionate about serving the province. 3. Good job security and benefits 4. Lots of opportunity for advancement if you find the right team/department. Plenty of variability in this depending on where in PHSA you work. Every program and team is unique.
cons: 1. Some co-workers have sub-par performance and don't get let go. Can be frustrating to work with. 2. Compensation and promotions are sometimes questionable and based less on performance than you would expect. 3. Department-level and organization-level changes are slow (ex: using skype still, slow approval of funding for permanent positions). If you can look past the many small things that are frustrating as a result of this bureaucracy then it makes the pros of working here worth it and the job highly rewarding.

pros: friendly and supportive people, learning lunches
cons: high load of work with lots of pressure and stress. low life-work balance. training not included for the job

review_title: It's a great Health Authority to work for
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Vancouver, BC
pros: Leaders are quite supportive and friendly. Fair salary negotiation and lots of job and opportunities. Excellent health and pension benefits.
cons: Office politics drain my daily work life, but if you've worked in retail or customer service, this shouldn't be a huge issue. It is definitely necessary to possess a high EQ to work in such a challenging and high stress work environment.

pros: Great benefits, they really care about your well being. Staff is very supportive.
cons: Union staff can be a bit disengaged. Executive leadership are not transparent.

pros: stable, good benefit, extra pay for OT
cons: night , evening and weekend shift

pros: Great co-workers if you don't make them irritated The premiums is amazing Time goes by fast during the high season Sometimes the supervisor can be very reassuring and supportive The job is easy if you get the hang of it Sometimes during low peak hours the job can get boring During the holidays expect lots of shifts and a wicked paycheck If you get a part-time / perm line congrats! You can get cross trained at more than one site( hospital) so more work!
cons: Supervisors don't know how to even operate the switchboard No team leads No leadership/ the "I don't get paid enough to do training or train ppl" is strong in this work place Casual isn't really casual/ if you reject a certain amount of shifts, expect a email from the supervisor You can't really talk to your supervisors about the job The "senior operators", if they don't like you for whatever reason or just want to look good, WILL find anything they can to make problems with you and the supervisor The supervisor has her favorites Work place gossip is REAL - just don't get involved Can be repetitive You sit for long hours If you're working a night shift and the graveyard calls in and no one else is available, be prepared to stay and work into the morning. And if that 6-2 calls in and no one is available be prepared to stay till there's enough staff to allow you to go home. So if you have another job it can clash. It's a 365 24/7 operation so be prepared to work a graveyard Long term employees don't move, some of them have been waiting 10+ years to get a line ( for example a mon -fri 830-430 work period). So opportunities to get permanent work is very limited Turnover for casuals is super high - I wonder why...

pros: It is a job that pays bills
cons: A lot of work, overworked

job_title: Business Analyst and Project Support in Vancouver, BC
pros: Some good colleagues and managers, depending on the team you are with. Good work-life balance if you are strict with your time. Relatively good annual leave / benefits / sick leave.
cons:
Management fills their calendars with meetings that they probably don't need to be a part of. Seems to be either a micromanager, or are hard to get in touch with when you need them. 
Pay is average at best, with the minimal increase annually that does not keep up with cost-of-living. Almost zero opportunity for growth within the company - they would rather hire externally than promote someone internally who has proven to be a good worker. A lot of life-time government workers who do the bare minimum to complete their job. No reward or recognition for going above and beyond. Finally allowing some WFH now due to COVID, however many teams are pushing employees to go back into the office for no apparent reason. Archaic technology (Skype).

review_title: Psychological Health & Safety team in HR is toxic
pros: Lots of options for internal mobility.
cons:
Ironically the Psychological Health & Safety team in HR is psychologically unsafe. The leaders treat staff poorly - they are controlling, condescending, and unprofessional.  Staff aren't  heard and are not respected.

There is also a fair degree of incompetence. The team's products are not meeting the needs of most staff and services are not well attended. PHSA staff deserve and need much better from a team with such an important function.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technologist I in Vancouver, BC
pros:
-extended health benefits (but which company doesn't have that nowadays)
-short-staffed (so you can experience and upskill and take on all the tasks to upskill even harder!)
-Sacrifice your own health for the health of others! (very admirable!)
cons:
-your salary increases by one dollar every year, and 70 cents depending on your union and it caps out 5 years later. (so. nothing pretty much in vancouver.)
-Mentally draining
-Before pandemic, all is well, the moment pandemic comes, you realize how insignificant your well-being is to them, despite being a health professional. 
(overworked, tired., short-staffed) and they still haven't posted those positions for people to apply. to "save money".

review_title: Great place to work during the pandemic!
pros: Ability to work evenings, great co-workers.
cons: Managers were sometimes unsure of processes.

pros: Good benefits like dental, extended health and pension plan.
cons:
No opportunities for career growth. The organization values seniority over competence - for instance, if two staff were to apply for an internal position for career advancement, the staff with higher seniority would be favored even if the other staff is more competent to do the job. 
The organization is highly bureaucratic - and i think it is a function of how large the company is. Selection of vacation days too is hinged on seniority. As a junior staff, you are likely not to go on vacation in summer/Xmas because the older employees have selected those prime slots. 
Overall, the pay is not that great for the amount of work you put in.

pros:

review_title: If you like doing meaningless routine without any impact this is the place to be
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Good pay for what you do.
Great work-life balance.
cons:
No culture, no respect, no feedback.
All decisions are top down, no tools to raise a hand and say smth. Many co-workers are so quiet like they do not exist. They say “staff’’, i hear “cattle”.
Work is pretty much around month-end (they have 13 though) and zero about forward-looking initiatives.
Finance does not have any authority and does not sign-off anything.
There is no competition, no challenges, no initiatives, nothing.
They do not have teams/zoom and literally no one leverages video skype.
They do not announce why they reward some teams and they do not call out the good work done.
Documents and presentations lack owners’ names and dates so it is impossible to find someone accountable or praise for a well job done later.

pros: Nice place to work , I enjoy working here
cons: None so far in my tenure

pros: pay is ok, benefits meh.
cons: Interpersonal skills are lacking and have been going down fast at PHSA WFM. Lack of training, culture, or career growth. Most notably. People in senior and managerial roles surprisingly interrupt meetings (as they think its ok the longer they been there and choose to run things under their own rules), regularly missed meetings among stakeholders without notice, lack of email replies in a way to not take responsibility or ownership, and unpaid overtime is expected. Most of all, is unspoken requested long hours to fix system jiras from an over-customized solution and deviation from most project plans!Thank goodness ability to finally WFH during pandemic. Otherwise WFH isn't allowed at all except been recently called into office.

pros: Lots of different areas to work, opportunities.
cons: Short staffed. Leadership removed from clinical care.

pros: The unit chief and the paramedics begged and pleaded with me to join BC Ambulance, it was good for the community so I tried. My condition was that I would work only week day shifts but would be available on short notice if needed. In 3 months I worked about 60 shifts and saw 19 patients.
cons:
Treatment of and respect for employees is abysmal.
ONE example: I was hired as a Driver Only with the understanding that I would find and complete an EMR course. Since I am in a small community it was agreed that BCAS would pay expenses for an out of town course. I found courses but was told "no" there would an "in town course" soon. As soon as the deadline for the courses I had found passed, the "in town" course would be cancelled and I was told to find another. BCAS did tell me on Dec 27 that there was a course in Stewart Jan 4, that they would pay expenses for. Since I live on Haida Gwaii this was impossible because planes and ferries are fully booked at that time of year. 
The same situation occurred for proctoring of Code 3 driving, I never did get cleared for Code 3 despite making arrangements with proctors at other ambulance stations, those arrangements were always cancelled because it was too expensive and a proctor was "going to come to Haida Gwaii soon", it never happened.
The final straw was when I got a letter (from a manager) telling me I had to show more "determination, initiative and perseverance" to remain an employee of BCHS. I went to the ambulance station and quit on the spot.
As far as initiative, perseverance and determination is concerned, I believe I have proven that; I have 4 university degrees, two are doctoral level. And I did have a successful career.

review_title: Not a good place for a young and ambitious tech professional
pros:
* Excellent medical benefits
* Transparent and predictable pay scales
* Protection from unreasonable time and duty demands
cons:
* Change moves extremely slowly and tech is often egregiously out of date
* Over-reliance on seniority -- someone barely qualified for a job is often the one doing it, not someone who's great at it
* Implicit ageist bias against younger staff -- older staff can often be dismissive and paternalistic of younger staff's suitability or insight
* Over-protection of problem employees can swiftly destroy team morale
* Inadequate training for my role beyond basic safety and workplace orientations, no official support for peer mentorship, very hard-to-access training budget

review_title: Humiliated during training and Manager said I wasn't there
pros:
Govt Job
Big corp, have chance to move up and/or other positions
Some positions are union, not all
cons:
Inadequate training
Favoritism
lack of trust
During my 3rd week of training, I was shouted at, humiliate in front of others about not being able to do the job, comparing me to someone who has left few days ago, how I am not the person she had requested her manager, and needs things done quicker.  She was a woman who was their go to person, a senior and manager knew she is hot tempered as he always felt awkward during her training  - If a man wold have shouted like that, it would have been national news . The whole office was watching and no one said a word, I kept silent and did the right thing by telling the Manager. The Manager didn't call to apologize, instead asked her 'something' and I could hear her mocking me, I quit and on the last day it was a passive apology telling me he wasn't there to witness it. The most disgusting insult, since I have to move on to other jobs and better not to burn bridges , I kept quiet
I wish I had recorded the whole thing

pros: The entry level jobs and pay are competitive, and you have access to a huge network of Health Care departments and employees to learn from (however, this might depend on your role). It is a great learning environment for fresh graduates or employees with less work experience. There are also a lot of competent and smart individuals trapped in entry level roles; these employees, if put in the right position, can potentially help make this organization better in all aspects,.
cons:
Career growth: Your career progression mostly hinges on corporate/ department politics. I have observed that your skill and experience level are either slightly relevant or totally irrelevant in your career progression. In other words, becoming your boss's favorite get's you on the fast track program (this might also be the case in many other companies). 

Decision making: Top level decision making is quite subpar, and valuable information from the front line is usually hindered from entering the decision making process because of insecure management.

review_title: Good benefits and stable job, lack of advancement opportunities.
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Vancouver, BC
pros: Flexible work hours, work life balance, good compensation package with 4 weeks vacation to start with, people are very kind in general, it depends on which team you work for, you could have very different view of the company. After all, it's the supervisor's management style that really affects the employees view.
cons: Lack of career advancement opportunities, the manager is afraid of losing his/her position and spent a lot of time to do things to make sure his/her position is secured. I can understand their view as when it gets to recession, the middle management is the layer that will be get rid of. However, their act is preventing the team being more efficient and blocks employee's opportunities of moving ahead either in developing their technical skills or moving up, this resulted in high turn over rate.

review_title: Management were very hard to work for and duplicitous
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Vancouver, BC
pros: A good feeling that your job has a direct impact on helping people
cons:
* Management are liars and make promises all the time to break them less than a year later.
* Management will support abusive personalities if those people are the "only people" who know a system.  Saw this happen over and over again.  Very Toxic
* Buildings are old, run down and the air quality is very poor.  
* ABSOLUTELY NO RAISES ON MERIT EVER!  You get paid what everyone else does regardless of union or not.
* Never any money to do any actual quality work so your always scraping bottom of the barrel for people, resources and results.  Makes for many failed projects with no consequences.
* If you are the type of person who doesn't like to do any work, read the internet all day, shun all activities and generally become a complete waste of effort, this is the place for you.  The Health Authority is completely incapable of firing anyone.

review_title: Large company...easy to get lost within, dependent on your sector
job_title: Laboratory Medical Technologist in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great benefits as a union employee, employee perks ( wireless Corp plans, employee discounts, etc). Convenient, accessible location (hospital setting). Vacation allowance starts at 20 days, tops at 35, and 5-day bonuses given at 25 yrs and ?30 yrs.
cons: Benefits aren't as good for excluded employees (still good, but not as good as union benefits), difficult to advance vertically, as a consolidated employee, tendency to feel disconnected from the company since most other departments are of another health authority, involvement in PSHA Corporate seems to be who you know that will advance you. Lack of educational funding for personal and professional advancement. Can be a "lifer" here.Union vacation policies are horrible (must book all vacation for the following year by Dec 31)

pros: Decent pay, 4 weeks of vacation for new hires in excluded positions, good medical benefits, pension, relaxed atmosphere
cons: I have a Master's degree and I feel my skills have been slowly disappearing the longer I work here; no possibility of promotion; I have worked here for a while and the pay raises are very minimal... they don't even cover the cost of living increases so essentially you are getting pay decreases over time... and there were 3 years where there was a pay freeze and no one got a pay raise; everyone works in silos, no one talks to each other; high degree of politics (but I have worked in other health authorities and this is everywhere in the public sector); management is very reactive rather than being proactive; constant reorganization but changes take forever to happen

review_title: Good team, smart driven people, lots of opportunities, high expectation.
pros: Good compensation and benefits, excellent paid training, wide exposure, lot of opportunities and challenges, nice office, some good people.
cons: High expectation if you are the not the right fit. Managers may not be supportive and can be harsh. The person from Human Resources that I worked with was not supportive and helpful at all and fueled my departure. Workload is high and effort is not always recognized.

pros: PHSA provides it's employees with generous amounts of freedom to structure work hours to meet your personal needs.  The management pay scale is good for a pseudo-governemnt agency but still lower than the private sector.  Good benefits and vacation entitlements retain staff.
cons: PHSA is quite poor at recognizing employee performance.  Senior managers are elusive.  The company is too decentralized to foster strong management principles - it is easy for managers and staff to avaoid each other and avoid accountability.

review_title: Review from the perspective of a corporate drone
job_title: Applications Support Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are nice, and minimum 4 weeks vacation is a really nice as well.
cons: Structuring of salaries is broken, like most places, wherein you'd have to leave and come back in order to get a reasonable raise, otherwise you're stuck with 2 to  3% raises per year which can be terribly slow depending on how high your salary starts at.

pros: Large company with good benefits, some excellent leaders in the operations; organization overall is providing valuable services to BC residents
cons: Historical high turnover in BP team is a directly result of: incompetent senior leadership team, lack of processes which cause reworks, lots of political games, leaders like to play favoritism, lack of career advancement opportunity (leaders are all hired externally), no professional development, senior leadership never pays attention to staff or encourage staff (only time you hear from them is when you make a mistake), not a good place if you want to advance in your career.

review_title: Good overall but certainly discouraging in many ways often beyond your departments control
pros: Decent pay, employees felt valued by immediate supervisors.  Some great people overall to work with that are certainly doing their best with what they have.  In my position it was nice to provide support to some of the hard working nurses and doctors in a meaningful way.
cons: Really big disconnect between other departments and ours.  Not much in the terms of advancement.  Severely limited with resources and yet constantly challenged to provide more and more which ultimately lead to a lot of stress and frustration.

review_title: Not for the ambitious or they young.
pros:
- Competitive starting salary
- Defined benefit pension plan
- 4 weeks vacation
- Ample opportunity to slack off and do as little as possible while getting paid
cons:
- Salary will only increase by 1-2% annually
- Roles are purely operational with no room for innovation
- Average age is 35 and up
- Others take advantage of the opportunity to slack off, even if you don't

review_title: Profits over patient care is the bottom line
pros: benefit package/pension is good, work location is well maintained for safety and ease of work for staff.  ergonomics are very good.  most managers are willing to listen to your concerns and try to work out a resolution to the benefit of both parties.
cons: whole departments being contracted out, inept managers, no consistency in maintaining rules. Dependent on individual managers as to what staff "can get away with."  Managers who are not qualified to manage and yet they continue to work and make stupid mistakes and get away with it.

review_title: Professionals micromanaged and treated like children
job_title: Allied Health Professional in Vancouver, BC
pros: Clinically, there are opportunities to work with specialized populations at Sunnyhill
cons:
Sunnyhill specificaly -Micromanagement extreme, managers have very poor leadership and communications skills.  Working as a professional in this environment is very negative. Little chance for ongoing learning as this is not support f
By management. Management completely unaware of clinical responsibilities and over involve themselves in unnecessary details. You have to ask for permission to do your job

review_title: Dynamic work environment with room for growth
job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: The HR team is very large.  You definitely have the opportunity to learn different parts of the business and gain experience in all areas of HR
cons: Large public organizations can be very slow to make decisions or take action.  Work load can be overwhelming at times, but you will have the support of your leaders.

pros: Good location of the office.
cons: PHSA is a big organization and therefore has a extremely rigid structure. The sub agency is lack of its own identify, and sometimes with competing identify with other individual research group. The upper management people are somewhat aware of the current issue, but all they care about is to flatten out the existing issue under the existing outdated mandate.

pros: Feels smaller than other Authorities. Less layers of management due to silos of agencies..  Less union angst than other Authorities. Nice generally happy culture.
cons: Senior Management not diverse. Selectively hire for those who look like and think like them instead of skills and experience.

pros: None whatsoever, I was told that I am being let go because of union seniority, in reality they merged 2 departments and just were looking for waste to cut costs
cons: No medical, dental, paid vacation or pension plan, Unhelpful HEU, I was not paid for the last week of my work, there are 2 people performing the same volume of work I was doing 🤣, that’s how incompetent the management is, not to mention a waste of resources as I trained on 2 ERP systems, I had to work for a year next to a person that talked to herself.

pros:
flexible everything, including time, location and duration of work week
excellent colleagues and relatively decent offices
great skills development and enhancement opportunities across a range of activities
cons:
zero upwards mobility
poor quality and very costly compulsory health insurance and benefits plan
horrific office location 
little IT flexibility in terms of systems, applications, and remote working options

review_title: Grew professionally but didn't feel safe
pros: Challenging, meaningful work in specialized health care agencies. Committed frontline practitioners. Fair compensation and vacation. Supports continuous learning.
cons:
Limited innovation in an environment that adheres strictly to evidence-based decision-making. Adopting a proven best practice from another healthcare organization is as innovative as you will get. 
Hierarchical, command and control culture prevails. Lateral violence and bullying (blaming, name-calling, withholding information, excluding from meetings) is permissable in mid-level leadership.

review_title: Stable, maybe a little too stable
pros: Stable, decent benefits. Huge employer means in theory plenty of opportunities to move within the org once you're in.
cons: Unionized environment means on the one hand your job is pretty secure, but on the other hand so is everyone else's. It's hard to advance professionally and training budgets are not abundant.

job_title: Intermediate Business Analyst in Vancouver, BC
pros: In the IMITs area there are a lot of nice, respectful and intelligent people to work with.  The culture and environment is one of respect and consideration.  I loved working there.
cons: Although I was hired as Business Analyst, the role turned out to be 70% tier 2 support for end users.

review_title: One of the best job with minimal education
job_title: Primary Care Paramedic in Vancouver, BC
pros: rewarding job that pays above average, respected occupation, lots advancements, lots to learn, lots kind people,
cons: Has to start part time(in BC), Has to start in remote/rural area, high divorce rate job, takes 5+ years to get a regular full time shift pattern

pros: Excellent healthcare benefits and family friendly policies in theory. Funding for continued education is retroactive only
cons: Corporate culture varies widely by agency and division. Some areas are very toxic and others are wonderful.  Salaries are low and huge amounts of money are misallocated.

pros: public health care pluses such as not having to charge patients for most services
cons: public sector minuses such as rationing of care and increasing bureaucratic micromanagement

pros: The company benefits are good.  Pension and health, dental & vision.
cons: It's a large organization.  It really does not care about staff.  Every department/unit is different.  There is alot politics and passive agressive behaviour from management.

review_title: Dedicated people, poor culture and engagement
pros: Dedicated people who care passionately about patients, and improving health outcomes for British Columbians.
cons: Lack of organizational identity and pride, low engagement.

pros: Great benefits. Decent wages. Working for a greater good. Often intelligent, caring colleagues.
cons: Very large organization, therefore inflexible and slow to adopt new technology.  As it is a collection of different programs & services, it doesn't really have an identity.

review_title: I have been working at Provincial Health Services full time
pros: Great benefits. Great people and fulfilling work with lots of areas you can move to and expand your skill set
cons: As its government, there can be a lot of bureaucracy which means things can move slowly

pros: I have enjoyed working here as PHSA gets impact and understands their staff.  My manager and colleagues are supportive
cons: Growth Opportunities, Resources, Compensation,   I can't think of other ones.

pros: Union agreement helps with special and personal leaves. Job stability is well secure
cons: For my current job I am unable to work outside of the facility. We  wish we had jobs where we could work on the go, maybe at home.

review_title: Strong work ethic required as staffing is slim.
pros: Management and Staff are understanding of the deep funding cuts.
cons: Long hours needed for excluded employees.

pros: I have a good and very understanding manager.
cons: It was extremely difficult to move around within the company through internal postings as most of them already had people in mind for the position before it was actually posted.

pros: You can move around the organization into different roles and the benefits are fantastic
cons: They don't encourage growth or support education and training.  You have to work really hard to go anywhere and no one seems to care.

pros: Good co-workers and workplace culture.
cons: overtime is based on seniority meaning all the older nurses take up all the OT so very hard to make more money.

review_title: Pleasant working environment but perhaps a bit siloed and institutionalized

polite management

very institutionalized
limited role scope

review_title: not a place a healthy working environment --too much politics in management

cons: Low salary, very political, poor managers who don't value their employees.

pros: Team work and co-workers are nice

Give contracts out to people who so lousy jobs.  Corrupt seniors management forging contracts with frauds.  There is no diversity.  Senior management are all white people.

pros: I am a casual employee at PHSA and always find the staff, as well as my supervisor are very supportive and helpful.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about the company.

pros: Small team within a large organisation - so had a mix of both things to benefit from.
cons: Office space for my team wasn't great, but given this was public money, it's hard to complain.

pros: PHSA has acknowledge the value of information systems and a unified patient experience
cons: Fragmented governance. Getting better, but still needs a lot of work.

pros: strong starting salary for difficulty of work and role in organisation.
cons: limited opportunities to grow in the role, however generally strong support from management for educational opportunities. limited direct colleagues to work with.
